qas.question: Which group of animal has a lower body temperature that marsupials and placentals?
Which time period is suggested that cynodonts had a high metabolic rate?
Why is it necessary for smaller animals to have an insulative covering?

answers.text: maintenance of a high and stable body temperature

qas.question: What does evidence found suggest about monotremes?
What do therians need to maintain a stable body temperature?

plausible_answers.text: lower body temperatures and more variable metabolic rates

qas.question: What do small animals have compared to therians?

plausible_answers.text: Some of the evidence found so far

qas.question: What suggests that monotremes have high metabolic rates?

plausible_answers.text: the maintenance of a high and stable body temperature

qas.question: What do placentals use their fur covering for?

context: When endothermy first appeared in the evolution of mammals is uncertain. Modern <a0_0>monotremes<a0_0/> have <b5_0>lower body temperatures and more variable metabolic rates<b5_0/> than marsupials and placentals, but there is evidence that some of their ancestors, perhaps including ancestors of the therians, may have had body temperatures like those of modern therians. <b6_0>Some of the evidence found so far<b6_0/> suggests that <a1_0>Triassic<a1_0/> cynodonts <b3_0>had fairly high metabolic rates<b3_0/>, but it is not conclusive. For small animals, <b4_0>an insulative covering like fur<b4_0/> is necessary for <b7_0>the <a2_0>maintenance of a high and stable body temperature<b7_0/><a2_0/>.
